segment.source: Download and install Windows PE (WinPE) so you can boot from a USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive
segment.target: Download and install Windows PE (WinPE) so you can boot from a USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive

segment.source: Download and install Windows PE (WinPE) so you can boot from a USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive
segment.target: Download and install Windows PE (WinPE) so you can boot from a USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive

segment.source: Download and install Windows PE (WinPE) so you can boot from a USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive
segment.target: Download and install Windows PE (WinPE) so you can boot from a USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive

segment.source: Boot your PC to a VHD file ("native boot") by using the BCDEdit tool.
segment.target: Boot your PC to a VHD file ("native boot") by using the BCDEdit tool.

segment.source: If you are adding the VHD to a computer that already has a Windows 10 or Windows 8 installation, you will have to add a boot entry to the menu.
segment.target: If you are adding the VHD to a computer that already has a Windows 10 or Windows 8 installation, you will have to add a boot entry to the menu.

segment.source: If you are adding the VHD to a computer that is running an older version of Windows, for example Windows Server 2008, you will have to update the system partition using the BCDboot tool and then modify the boot menu using the BCDedit tool.
segment.target: If you are adding the VHD to a computer that is running an older version of Windows, for example Windows Server 2008, you will have to update the system partition using the BCDboot tool and then modify the boot menu using the BCDedit tool.

segment.source: Native boot for Windows 10 requires the .vhdx format, not the .vhd format.
segment.target: Native boot for Windows 10 requires the .vhdx format, not the .vhd format.

segment.source: Update the Boot Menu to Add a VHD
segment.target: Update the Boot Menu to Add a VHD

segment.source: To update a BIOS-based computer to include a Windows 8 boot menu
segment.target: To update a BIOS-based computer to include a Windows 8 boot menu

segment.source: Copy the .vhdx file to the destination computer.
segment.target: Copy the .vhdx file to the destination computer.

segment.source: For example, at a command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, at a command prompt, type:

segment.source: Use the DiskPart tool in Windows PE to attach the VHD on the destination computer.
segment.target: Use the DiskPart tool in Windows PE to attach the VHD on the destination computer.

segment.source: You can attach a VHD by using the Attach vdisk command.
segment.target: You can attach a VHD by using the Attach vdisk command.

segment.source: This enables the VHD so that it appears on the host as a disk drive instead of as a .vhdx file.
segment.target: This enables the VHD so that it appears on the host as a disk drive instead of as a .vhdx file.

segment.source: At a command prompt, type:
segment.target: At a command prompt, type:

segment.source: Use the BCDboot tool, located in the System32 directory of the VHD image or in Windows PE to copy the boot environment files and Boot Configuration Data (BCD) configuration from the Windows directory in the VHD to the system partition.
segment.target: Use the BCDboot tool, located in the System32 directory of the VHD image or in Windows PE to copy the boot environment files and Boot Configuration Data (BCD) configuration from the Windows directory in the VHD to the system partition.

segment.source: On a computer that has BIOS firmware, the system partition is the active partition of the first hard disk.
segment.target: On a computer that has BIOS firmware, the system partition is the active partition of the first hard disk.

segment.source: For example, to use BCDboot from the VHD image, at a command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, to use BCDboot from the VHD image, at a command prompt, type:

segment.source: The BCDboot tool automatically imports information from the existing installation when updating the BCD.
segment.target: The BCDboot tool automatically imports information from the existing installation when updating the BCD.

segment.source: The computer is now updated to include a Windows 8 boot environment.
segment.target: The computer is now updated to include a Windows 8 boot environment.

segment.source: You can now follow the steps in the section "To add a native-boot VHD to an existing Windows 8 boot menu" later in this topic.
segment.target: You can now follow the steps in the section "To add a native-boot VHD to an existing Windows 8 boot menu" later in this topic.

segment.target: To update a UEFI-based computer to include a Windows 8 boot menu

segment.source: Copy the .vhdx file to the destination computer.

segment.source: For example, at a command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, at a command prompt, type:

segment.source: Use the DiskPart tool in Windows PE to attach the VHD on the destination computer.
segment.target: Use the DiskPart tool in Windows PE to attach the VHD on the destination computer.

segment.source: You can attach a VHD by using the Attach vdisk command.
segment.target: You can attach a VHD by using the Attach vdisk command.

segment.source: This enables the VHD so that it appears on the host as a disk drive instead of as a .vhdx file.
segment.target: This enables the VHD so that it appears on the host as a disk drive instead of as a .vhdx file.

segment.source: On a UEFI-based computer, the system partition is hidden by default and must be assigned a drive letter before you run the BCDboot tool.
segment.target: On a UEFI-based computer, the system partition is hidden by default and must be assigned a drive letter before you run the BCDboot tool.

segment.source: Use the DiskPart tool to locate the EFI system partition and assign a drive letter to it.
segment.target: Use the DiskPart tool to locate the EFI system partition and assign a drive letter to it.

segment.source: At a command prompt, type:
segment.target: At a command prompt, type:

segment.source: Where x is the 100 megabyte (MB) EFI system partition that is formatted with FAT.
segment.target: Where x is the 100 megabyte (MB) EFI system partition that is formatted with FAT.

segment.source: Use the BCDboot tool, located in the System32 directory of the VHD image or in Windows PE to copy the boot environment files and BCD configuration from the Windows directory in the VHD to the system partition.
segment.target: Use the BCDboot tool, located in the System32 directory of the VHD image or in Windows PE to copy the boot environment files and BCD configuration from the Windows directory in the VHD to the system partition.

segment.target: The BCDboot tool automatically imports information from the existing installation when updating the BCD.

segment.source: The computer is now updated with a Windows 10 boot environment.
segment.target: The computer is now updated with a Windows 10 boot environment.

segment.source: You can now follow the steps to add a native-boot VHD to an existing boot menu.
segment.target: You can now follow the steps to add a native-boot VHD to an existing boot menu.

segment.source: To add a native-boot VHD to an existing Windows 8 boot menu
segment.target: To add a native-boot VHD to an existing Windows 8 boot menu

segment.source: Back up your BCD store using the BCDedit tool with the /export option.
segment.target: Back up your BCD store using the BCDedit tool with the /export option.

segment.source: When the computer restarts, the boot menu will display all of the Windows installations on the computer and boot into the VHD after the operating-system selection countdown is completed.
segment.target: When the computer restarts, the boot menu will display all of the Windows installations on the computer and boot into the VHD after the operating-system selection countdown is completed.
